Line 43: Line 43:
==2011 Egyptian revolution==
==2011 Egyptian revolution==
  +
[[File:Wael Khalil.jpg|thumb|Wael Khalil]]
Khalil was active during the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]] and its aftermath.
Khalil was active during the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]] and its aftermath.
Line 50: Line 51:
==2011 Budget policy==
==2011 Budget policy==
â
[[File:Wael Khalil.jpg|thumb|Wael Khalil]]
+
[[File:Wael Khalil speaking at Tweet Nadwa.jpg|thumb|Wael Khalil speaking at Tweet Nadwa about the 2011 Budget]]
In a June 2011 editorial in ''[[The Guardian]]'', Khalil criticized support from the [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF), which included a $3 billion loan.<ref>{{cite web|last=Werr |first=Patrick |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/05/us-egypt-imf-idUSTRE7541AA20110605 |title=Egypt seals $3 billion IMF accord |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-06-05 |accessdate=2011-07-20}}</ref> He said, "But many people, myself included, were unhappy with this news and the impact such a loan will have on deepening the country's debt and mounting debt servicing burden."<ref name="guardian1">{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/jun/07/egypt-imf-loan |title=Egypt's IMF-backed revolution? No thanks | Wael Khalil | Comment is free | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-07-20}}</ref> Khalil equated help from the bank with "neoliberal[ism]", "imperialism", and the politics of the Mubarak regime. He blamed such policies for economic stagnation, deterioration, and growing inequality under Mubarak. Khalil cited IMF ex-employee and Mubarak regime finance minister [[Youssef Boutros-Ghali]], who was sentenced to prison for corruption. He said, "I believe that this country's future lies not with the same highly paid, unelected, unaccountable bureaucrats of the IMF, nor with their sacred indicators of budget deficits and market economics. Our future lies with a new home-grown economics that caters for the majority of Egyptians, the schools where their children are educated, the hospitals where they receive healthcare, and the jobs that guarantee them decent and honourable living."<ref name="guardian1"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Ben |first=Danny |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=226639 |title=By rejecting IMF loan Egypt risks undermin... JPost - Middle East |publisher=Jpost.com |date=2011-06-26 |accessdate=2011-07-20}}</ref>
In a June 2011 editorial in ''[[The Guardian]]'', Khalil criticized support from the [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF), which included a $3 billion loan.<ref>{{cite web|last=Werr |first=Patrick |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/05/us-egypt-imf-idUSTRE7541AA20110605 |title=Egypt seals $3 billion IMF accord |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-06-05 |accessdate=2011-07-20}}</ref> He said, "But many people, myself included, were unhappy with this news and the impact such a loan will have on deepening the country's debt and mounting debt servicing burden."<ref name="guardian1">{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/jun/07/egypt-imf-loan |title=Egypt's IMF-backed revolution? He blamed such policies for economic stagnation, deterioration, and growing inequality under Mubarak. Khalil cited IMF ex-employee and Mubarak regime finance minister [[Youssef Boutros-Ghali]], who was sentenced to prison for corruption. He said, "I believe that this country's future lies not with the same highly paid, unelected, unaccountable bureaucrats of the IMF, nor with their sacred indicators of budget deficits and market economics. Our future lies with a new home-grown economics that caters for the majority of Egyptians, the schools where their children are educated, the hospitals where they receive healthcare, and the jobs that guarantee them decent and honourable living."<ref name="guardian1"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Ben |first=Danny |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=226639 |title=By rejecting IMF loan Egypt risks undermin... JPost - Middle East |publisher=Jpost.com |date=2011-06-26 |accessdate=2011-07-20}}</ref>
